newsitem.title: INDIA: India airline debate reveals economic policy split.
newsitem.headline: India airline debate reveals economic policy split.

text.p: A battle over aviation policy has exposed a gaping split in India's coalition government between free traders and defenders of domestic industry.
Civil Aviation Minister C.M. Ibrahim said late on Monday that the centre-left government was drafting a new policy that would bar foreign investment in domestic airlines.

Hours later, newspapers revealed that a panel of senior government officials headed by the Industry Ministry had approved a proposed investment by Singapore Airlines Ltd (SIA) in a joint airlines venture with India's Tata Industries.
Analysts said the divergent tacks reflect simmering contradictions and disarray within Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda's disparate 13-party coalition.
"This shows a lack of coordination in the cabinet," said Vinod Mehta, editor of the weekly news magazine Outlook.

"It is a chaotic government because Deve Gowda has never worked in the Centre (federal government) and doesn't know how to suppress disruptions," said Ashok Desai, a newspaper columnist and former senior finance ministry official.
It was not the first time Ibrahim had squared off with the Industry Ministry.

Earlier this year the Foreign Investment Promotion Board (FIPB), an advisory panel comprised of senior officials and headed by Industry Secretary N. Mohanty, cleared a proposal by Britain's Pearson Plc, publisher of the Financial Times, to take an equity stake in an Indian newspaper company.
Ibrahim, who is also information and broadcasting minister, mounted a campaign against the link-up, which was later rejected by the Cabinet Committee on Foreign Investment.
The high-profile Ibrahim has used the same boundless energy to fight against foreign investment in the airlines sector.
In an ironic twist, he has won political backing from the government's left-wing allies and the right-wing opposition.

The Communist Party of India-Marxist and the right-wing Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) both denounced the FIPB's move to clear the proposed $600 million SIA-Tata linkup and to send it to the cabinet for a final decision.

Ibrahim, who comes from Deve Gowda's home state of Karnataka, says India's state-owned carriers -- Indian Airlines on domestic routes and Air-India internationally -- need to be strengthened before they face foreign competition.

He said on Monday that his ministry was drafting a new aviation policy that would block the SIA-Tata joint venture and, significantly, require the two foreign partners in India's Jet Airways -- Gulf Air and Kuwait Airways -- to sell their stakes.
However, he said foreign investment would be welcome in aviation infrastructure such as airports.
Currently the government reviews foreign firms' proposals on a case-by-case basis. If approved, a foreign firm can take up to a 40 percent stake in a domestic airline.
Ibrahim is at odds with the more liberal members of Deve Gowda's cabinet including Finance Minister P. Chidambaram and Industry Minister Murasoli Maran.
"There is a war going on," Desai said.
Ibrahim's more protectionist approach has periodically sent shivers down the spines of foreign investors, who fear the government will backtrack on free trade.
"The battle between the Industry Ministry and the Civil Aviation Ministry is likely to snowball into a major crisis on the foreign investment front," The Economic Times said.
Outlook editor Mehta predicted the SIA-Tata tie-up would eventually be approved and Ibrahim would have to back down after scoring political points by sticking up for domestic industry.

"Deve Gowda is a free trader," Mehta said. "The government wants to show there has been an enormous debate. But after four or five months, I think it (the tie-up) will be allowed, after announcing measures to strengthen Indian Airlines."
